meanings.definition: To coerce or force into doing something
meanings.sent1: The teacher tried to dragoon the students into completing their homework on time.
meanings.sent2: The bully tried to dragoon the younger kids into giving him their lunch money.
meanings.sent3: The coach jokingly threatened to dragoon the players into running extra laps if they didn't listen.
meanings.sent4: The strict manager would dragoon his employees into working overtime without proper compensation.
meanings.sent5: The drill sergeant's intense stare seemed to dragoon the recruits into following his every command.

meanings.definition: A member of a European military unit specializing in mounted infantry
meanings.sent1: The dragoon rode swiftly on horseback, ready for battle.
meanings.sent2: The dragoon's uniform was adorned with medals and badges of honor.
meanings.sent3: The young boy dressed up as a dragoon for Halloween, complete with a toy sword.
meanings.sent4: The dragoon's presence on the battlefield was both intimidating and strategic.
meanings.sent5: The dragoon's horse galloped gracefully as they patrolled the borders of the kingdom.

meanings.definition: A type of firearm used by cavalry troops
meanings.sent1: The cavalry unit carried dragoons to defend themselves in battle.
meanings.sent2: The soldiers cleaned and maintained their dragoons before the upcoming mission.
meanings.sent3: The old dragoon displayed in the museum showcased the evolution of military weaponry.
meanings.sent4: The sound of the dragoon being fired echoed through the valley during the training exercise.
meanings.sent5: The shiny dragoon gleamed in the sunlight as it was handed over to the cavalry captain.
